steps.title: Let your Aloe Vera plant fill the pot it is in, when the plant fills the pot it will be ready to be repotted into a larger pot and will already have started to produce new shoots.
steps.content: Let your Aloe Vera plant fill the pot it is in, when the plant fills the pot it will be ready to be repotted into a larger pot and will already have started to produce new shoots. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Wait for the new shoots to grow to about two inches with at least two or three leaves emerging from the soil close to the adult plant.
steps.content: Wait for the new shoots to grow to about two inches with at least two or three leaves emerging from the soil close to the adult plant. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Prepare the new pot or container for transplanting the growing plant.
steps.content: Prepare the new pot or container for transplanting the growing plant. The new pot should be at least twice as big as the old pot and be clean so wash it with clean water and allow it to dry.

steps.title: Prepare the soil by breaking up the potting compost with your hands so there are no lumps.
steps.content: Prepare the soil by breaking up the potting compost with your hands so there are no lumps. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Add a handful of small stones or stone chips to the bottom of the pot to allow excess water to drain.
steps.content: Add a handful of small stones or stone chips to the bottom of the pot to allow excess water to drain. [5] X Expert Source Andi Xoch Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 4 August 2021.

steps.title: Place the soil on top of the stone chips and fill to the top of the pot.
steps.content: Place the soil on top of the stone chips and fill to the top of the pot. Plat down the soil and add some more soil so that it reaches about an inch from the top of the pot again.

steps.title: Gently remove the adult plant from its pot by turning the pot upside down and gently removing the plant.
steps.content: Gently remove the adult plant from its pot by turning the pot upside down and gently removing the plant.

steps.title: Place the plant on some old newspaper or card.
steps.content: Place the plant on some old newspaper or card.

steps.title: Carefully remove the soil from the plant roots and the new shoots.
steps.content: Carefully remove the soil from the plant roots and the new shoots. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Gently pull the new shoots away from the mother plant being careful not to damage the roots.
steps.content: Gently pull the new shoots away from the mother plant being careful not to damage the roots. Put the new shoots aside on the paper for replanting later. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Use a trowel to make a hole in the middle of the compost that is big enough for the adult plant to fit.
steps.content: Use a trowel to make a hole in the middle of the compost that is big enough for the adult plant to fit. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Gently place the adult Aloe Vera plant into the prepared hole.
steps.content: Gently place the adult Aloe Vera plant into the prepared hole.

steps.title: Add some more soil to fill in any gaps around the repotted plant.
steps.content: Add some more soil to fill in any gaps around the repotted plant.

steps.title: Pour a small amount of water over the entire surface of the pot.
steps.content: Pour a small amount of water over the entire surface of the pot. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Place your newly potted adult Aloe Vera in a sunny spot indoors or outdoors, if your climate permits.
steps.content: Place your newly potted adult Aloe Vera in a sunny spot indoors or outdoors, if your climate permits.

steps.title: Return to the new shoots on the newspaper and pot all of them into new containers using the same steps used to repot the adult plant.
steps.content: Return to the new shoots on the newspaper and pot all of them into new containers using the same steps used to repot the adult plant. [10] X Expert Source Andi Xoch Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 4 August 2021.
